issue.title: Update the connection reset exception detection

repository.name: Chronicle-Network
repository.description: A High Performance Network ( TCP/IP ) Library

issue.body:
...to prevent spurious warnings on connection reset, Fixes #172

See the issue for details.

It sucks that we have to inspect the exception this way, but given there's no ConnectionResetException I guess we have to suck it up for the time being.

body: There's also a problem when using non-English locale: the messages are different for every language and there's no way to get un-localized one. So when running on French or Chinese-language box, these messages will never be suppressed.

issue.title: Add warning when transient exception suppression is unavailable due…

repository.name: Chronicle-Network
repository.description: A High Performance Network ( TCP/IP ) Library

body:
> There's also a problem when using non-English locale: the messages are different for every language and there's no way to get un-localized one. So when running on French or Chinese-language box, these messages will never be suppressed.

This is as true as it is ridiculous. I fail to understand why any programmer ever would use a language other than English.

> There's also a problem when using non-English locale: the messages are different for every language and there's no way to get un-localized one. So when running on French or Chinese-language box, these messages will never be suppressed.

I think we might be "safe" because we use [getMessage](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/Throwable.html#getMessage--) not [getLocalizedMessage](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/Throwable.html#getLocalizedMessage--) but this is a dirty hack and we shouldn't be doing it anyway. I will spend a little but of time looking into whether we can do it without relying on the message.

@minborg Locale dictates things such as date format, number formatting, currency sign, etc, so it is important for an application to run in a correct locale. However, non-English locales will also cause some Java error messages to change. This made sense if you expect to show the exception message to the end-user, but it's a big problem of Java that you can't tell "connection reset" by looking at IOException.

@nicktindall Unfortunately, `getMessage()` is also localized :) :( and `getLocalizedMessage()` just returns `getMessage()`.

> @minborg Locale dictates things such as date format, number formatting, currency sign, etc, so it is important for an application to run in a correct locale. However, non-English locales will also cause some Java error messages to change. This made sense if you expect to show the exception message to the end-user, but it's a big problem of Java that you can't tell "connection reset" by looking at IOException.
> 
> @nicktindall Unfortunately, `getMessage()` is also localized :) :( and `getLocalizedMessage()` just returns `getMessage()`.

I fully support the use of Locale but changing language is just wrong.
